Geithner to discuss book on economic collapse

Jere Downs, jdowns@courier-journal.com 7:45 a.m. EDT October 27, 2014

Geithner (Photo: Joe Vericker, Photobureau )

Story Highlights

  • IF YOU GO
  • What: Kentucky Author Forum presents former U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner, interviewed by New Yorker magazine columnist James Surowiecki
  • Cost: $20 ticket includes reception, interview and Q&A; $110 ticket adds an 8:15 p.m. dinner in honor of Geithner and Surowiecki. Go to www.kentuckycenter.org.
  • Information: (502) 584-7777 or (800) 775-7777
8 CONNECT 4 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Housing price declines, job layoffs, tight loan terms and economic uncertainty are all lingering effects of the Great Recession, which officially ended in June 2009. How lax federal oversight of the banking system, Wall Street greed and consumers' mismanagement of their own personal finances combined to force the catastrophic economic collapse beginning in 2007 will be reviewed Nov. 3 by former U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner in a talk for the Kentucky Author Forum.

Geithner's speaking tour comes on the heels of the publication of his 580-page tome on how our economy unraveled, entitled "Stress Test, Reflections on Financial Crises." To help translate Geithner, a career bureaucrat whose book is laden with financial lingo, he will be interviewed on stage by New Yorker magazine columnist James Surowiecki.

Surowiecki regularly untangles financial news for everyday readers in "The Financial Page," his magazine column. And "Stress Test" is a read that was heavy going at times, even for this writer who covered the economic collapse for The Courier-Journal beginning in 2007.

And while the book was just published this year and appeared for five weeks on The New York Times Best Seller list, Geithner is not giving interviews to the media. His book was recently at the center of a lawsuit against the government. Maurice R. Greenberg, a former chief executive of A.I.G. has sued the government for $40 billion, claiming the U.S. Federal Reserve shortchanged shareholders by stepping in to rescue the insurance giant. A.I.G.'s troubles and subsequent government intervention are discussed throughout the book, which has been the subject of testimony at trial in October.

Former Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner talks about how the governments efforts during the financial crisis avoided a repeat of the Great Depression. Bobbi Rebell reports.

Readers of "Stress Test" come to understand exactly how oversight of banking and investments were broken before the recession, and the need for improved protection for consumers. The recent creation of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, for example, is a direct result of lending abuses that led up to the collapse of credit in the United States.

And while the recession touched the lives of most Americans, everyone may not be conversant in some of the financial arcana Geithner covers in his book. The good news is the book is peppered with expletives and personal insights into publicly reserved characters who struggled to stop panicked financial markets. To that end, see the guide below for some of the terms and concepts that may be bandied around between Geithner and Surowiecki on stage Nov. 3 at the Kentucky Center.

1. "Doomsday Book"

This is the secret binder maintained by the New York branch of the U.S. Federal Reserve discussing the government's powers in the event of a catastrophic banking crisis.

2. "Mt. Fuji"

This term refers to the chart on page 107 of the book that tracks the soaring growth of household mortgage debt, which spiked 63 percent between 2001 and 2007, fueled by lax lending standards.

3. "Haircut"

This is the term for the lower price an analyst or money manager may give to a stock as they anticipate its drop in value.

4. "Finger in the dyke"

This phrase comes up repeatedly throughout the book as Geithner, former U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke and others express powerlessness to contain runs on banking giants by panicked investors.

5. "Office of Thrift Supervision"

This federal agency, which had more lenient banking oversight than other regulatory agencies, oversaw crippled lending giants like Countrywide and Washington Mutual.

Former U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner spoke about his book, 'Stress Test,' on the financial crisis from his perspective, and he shared what it was like to serve President Bush and President Obama.

6. "The rivets came off the submarine."

One of the phrases regulators at the New York branch of the U.S. Federal Reserve used in 2007 as they sought to avert the collapse of federally backed housing lenders Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which funded three out of four U.S. mortgages. Other metaphors included "wheels coming off the bus," "sweaters unraveling," "boulders rolling down a hill" and "engines falling off the plane."

7. "His voice broke."

Geithner described former U.S. Treasury Secretary Hank Paulson's distraught report when the U.S. House of Representatives failed to approve the first draft of a $700 billion bank rescue plan in the fall of 2008.

8. "Depression 2.0"

The term former U.S. Federal Reserve chairman Ben Bernanke and Geithner used for the likelihood of a new Great Depression, one they were trying to avert by funneling capital to distressed banks, investment banks and insurers damaged by trading in subprime securities.

9. "Luca Brasi"

Reviled in the press for backing bank bailouts, Geitnner was once compared in a CNBC report to Luca Brasi, the fictional hit man for Don Corleone's character in "The Godfather" film series.

10. "Bromance"

This is the term David Axelrod, then top political aide to Obama, would give to the instantly warm relationship between the U.S. President and Geithner, who became his Secretary of the U.S. Treasury.

11. "Marinate him in my downsides"

This is the term Geithner used in the book when writing about delivering bad news to colleagues or business partners. It describes how he would elaborate worst case scenarios and pitfalls often and in broad detail to make the case for painful action.

12. "Death by deck"

Over exposure to decks of slides used in Powerpoint presentations in long meetings about the financial crises led to this term used by government and banking officials.

13. "Money in the window"

This is the term used by government and banking officials to describe how they would ease interest rates to soothe panicked investors, and show that credit could still be available, encouraging banks to lend.

14. "Lehman Syndrome"

This term describes a panicky state of mind, the book says, "a kind of financial post traumatic stress disorder." The name Lehman derives from the failed investment bank.

IF YOU GO

What: Kentucky Author Forum presents former U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner, interviewed by New Yorker magazine columnist James Surowiecki

When: Book sale and wine and cheese reception, 5 p.m.; interview and question-and-answer session, 7 p.m.

Cost: $20 ticket includes reception, interview and Q&A; $110 ticket adds an 8:15 p.m. dinner in honor of Geithner and Surowiecki. Go to www.kentuckycenter.org.
